G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and is sufficient to invoke the original jurisdiction of the Massachusetts Superior Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and/or 9.proposition: Venue is proper in the Norfolk County Superior Court, Quincy Division, pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and/or 9, because the cause of action arose in Norfolk County and Defendant conducts business in Norfolk County.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85;.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a lawful visitor and business invitee, a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a lawful visitor and business invitee, a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: The excerpt is a concurring opinion discussing the abandonment of common-law categories like licensee and invitee, and criticizing the continued special treatment of trespassers. It does not itself state or reaffirm the specific rule that a defendant owes a business invitee a duty of reasonable care to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition. While the majority opinion in Mounsey generally moves toward a unitary reasonable-care standard for lawful visitors, this particular quoted passage does not clearly articulate the claimed proposition.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a "licensee" rather than an "invitee," or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to take reasonable steps to protect her from foreseeable risks of harm, including dangerous conditions such as slippery, wet floors in common passageways and hallways used by customers.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.support_reasoning: The case does recognize that a landowner owes lawful entrants a common-law duty of reasonable care and a duty to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition, but its factual context and analysis concern an obviously dangerous trampoline–pool setup in a residential backyard, not slip-and-fall or wet-floor conditions in common passageways used by customers. The opinion focuses on the open-and-obvious-danger doctrine and the duty to remedy such dangers under Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343A, not on duties regarding slippery, wet floors in common areas. Thus it is not appropriate authority for the specific proposition about protecting customers from wet floors in common passageways.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … It also includes an obligation ‘to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.’”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to take reasonable steps to protect her from foreseeable risks of harm, including dangerous conditions such as slippery, wet floors in common passageways and hallways used by customers.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that property owners owe lawful visitors a general duty of reasonable care as to all hazards, and specifically extends that duty to hazards from snow and ice on areas used by customers, such as parking lots and walkways. The court abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and states that owners must act as a reasonable person under all the circumstances to protect lawful visitors from foreseeable harm arising from such conditions, which encompasses slippery floors, passageways, and similar common areas. Although this case involves an outdoor parking lot, the articulated duty rule is general and applies to common passageways used by customers.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Defendant further owed Plaintiff a duty to inspect areas open to the public, including the hallway between the dining room and restroom, and to remedy or warn of dangerous conditions that Defendant knew or reasonably should have known existed.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The case involves a common-carrier subway station, not a restaurant hallway, and it is cited here mainly for its detailed treatment of notice and circumstantial proof of how long a foreign substance has been present. Although the opinion recites the general duty of a business premises owner to use due care to keep areas reasonably safe or warn of unknown dangers, it does not specifically address a separate, heightened duty to inspect areas open to the public such as a hallway, nor does it elaborate on an affirmative inspection duty beyond the standard premises-liability formulation. Thus it only generally states the duty to maintain safe premises and warn, not the more specific inspection duty claimed.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.”

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc..raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 783–85 (2007)
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc..proposition: Defendant further owed Plaintiff a duty to inspect areas open to the public, including the hallway between the dining room and restroom, and to remedy or warn of dangerous conditions that Defendant knew or reasonably should have known existed.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc..case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc..support_reasoning: The case concerns a grocery store slip-and-fall on produce in a self-service supermarket aisle and adopts the mode-of-operation approach for such premises-liability claims. It discusses a store owner’s duty to maintain reasonably safe conditions and foresee risks inherent in its self-service operation, but it does not address duties related to inspecting or maintaining non-retail areas like hallways to restrooms or generally "areas open to the public" beyond the store’s merchandising areas. Thus it does not specifically support a duty to inspect and remedy conditions in a hallway between a dining room and restroom.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc..relevant_excerpt: Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property "in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk." … In sum, the adoption of the mode of operation approach will not modify the general rule governing premises liability requiring a plaintiff to prove that an owner had either actual or constructive notice of an unsafe condition on the premises.

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc..raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 782–85 (2007)
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner may be found negligent when it (1) created the dangerous condition; (2) had actual knowledge of the condition; or (3) had constructive knowledge because the condition existed for such a length of time that in the exercise of reasonable care it should have been discovered and remedied.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc..case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc..support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Sheehan describes the traditional Massachusetts premises liability rule—under which a plaintiff had to show the defendant created the condition, had actual notice, or had constructive notice based on the length of time the condition existed—but the case’s holding rejects that as the governing standard for self-service stores and adopts the mode-of-operation approach instead. Thus, while the opinion recounts that this was historically the Massachusetts rule, Sheehan is not authority that this remains the controlling Massachusetts law; it refines and partially displaces that standard in the context at issue.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc..relevant_excerpt: “Under the traditional approach to premises liability, the plaintiff is required to prove a grocery store caused a substance, matter, or item to be on the floor; the store operator had actual knowledge of its presence; or the substance, matter, or item had been on the floor so long that the store operator should have been aware of the condition. … Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability.”

*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.proposition: Independently, Defendant had constructive knowledge of the Water Hazard because it existed for at least several minutes—long enough that reasonable inspection and maintenance practices would have detected and corrected the condition prior to Plaintiff’s fall.
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses constructive notice based on the length of time a transient spill existed. The court holds that from the dirty, melted, tracked-through condition of the ice cream, plus the constant presence and vantage point of nearby cashiers, the jury could infer that the substance had been present for an “appreciable time” and “long enough to have been known of and removed” in the exercise of reasonable care. That directly supports the proposition that a defendant can have constructive knowledge of a water/slip hazard that exists for several minutes—long enough that reasonable inspection would have detected and corrected it before the fall.
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff’s right to recover therefore depends upon evidence from which the jury could find that the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of and removed this foreign substance… The record shows that the ice cream must have come upon the floor within the period of thirty minutes… Some appreciable time must have elapsed also for the ice cream to have gotten into the condition it was in… In Foley v. F. W. Woolworth Co. … the jury were warranted in drawing an inference… that it had been on the stairway long enough to have been known of and removed before the accident.”

*Mounsey*, 363 Mass. at 707; *Papadopoul.proposition: Defendant’s failure to take reasonable steps to remove or warn of the Water Hazard violated the duty of reasonable care as articulated in Massachusetts premises liability law.
*Mounsey*, 363 Mass. at 707; *Papadopoul.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is a concurrence in Mounsey criticizing continued reliance on entrant-status categories (like trespasser/licensee/invitee) and endorsing a more general negligence-based duty analysis. Mounsey, and later Papadopoulos, are well-known Massachusetts cases that abolish or narrow entrant-status distinctions and articulate a general duty of reasonable care in premises liability. While this excerpt does not mention snow, ice, or a specific "Water Hazard," the cases as cited (Mounsey, 363 Mass. at 707; Papadopoulos, 457 Mass. at 376–78) do stand for applying a reasonable care standard to conditions on land, so they support the proposition at the level of general duty. The support is indirect because the text provided is more about dismantling status categories than about removal or warning duties for a particular hazard.
*Mounsey*, 363 Mass. at 707; *Papadopoul.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct.

*Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass.raw_text: *Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass’n*, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 333, 336–38 (2010)
*Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass.proposition: To the extent Defendant contends that the Water Hazard was open and obvious, such contention does not eliminate Defendant’s duty where, as here, it was foreseeable that an invitee would encounter the condition in order to use necessary facilities (the restroom), and reasonable steps could have been taken to remedy or mitigate the danger.
*Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass.case_name: Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condominium Association
*Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that the open and obvious nature of an ice hazard does not negate the landowner’s duty to remedy it, particularly where the hazard lies in a known path of travel that people will foreseeably need to use. Although the case does not specifically mention restrooms, it adopts Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343A comment f, which covers situations where an invitee will proceed despite the danger to access needed facilities or advantages, and it applies that principle to a necessary route to the plaintiff’s car. Thus, it supports the broader proposition that open and obviousness does not eliminate the duty when it is foreseeable that invitees will encounter the condition and reasonable remedial steps could be taken.
*Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass.relevant_excerpt: “The Restatement recognizes that a property owner or possessor should not be relieved from remedying open and obvious dangers where he ‘can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the invitee notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.’… As the Restatement further recognizes, one of the specific circumstances where harm to others is foreseeable is ‘where the possessor has reason to expect that the invitee will proceed to encounter the known or obvious danger because to a reasonable man in his position the advantages of doing so would outweigh the apparent risk.’”

*Graci v. Damon*, 6 Mass. App. Ct. 160,.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for her injuries and damages in accordance with Massachusetts law.
*Graci v. Damon*, 6 Mass. App. Ct. 160,.support_reasoning: The opinion applies Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute to reduce the jury’s damages finding and discusses how to apportion and compare fault among multiple parties. It does not articulate any general rule about a plaintiff’s entitlement to recover "fair and reasonable compensation" for injuries as a standalone principle; rather, it assumes the damages figure found by the jury and focuses on statutory reduction based on comparative negligence. Thus, it does not meaningfully serve as authority for the broad proposition stated.
*Graci v. Damon*, 6 Mass. App. Ct. 160,.relevant_excerpt: The case was tried to a jury, who returned a special verdict ... finding Graci’s damages to be $16,300... The judge accordingly reduced the damages "in proportion to the amount of negligence attributable to the person for whose injury, damage or death recovery is made” (G. L. c. 231, § 85, as amended through St. 1969, c. 761), and entered separate judgments for the plaintiff for $13,855.00 (85% of $16,300) against each of the defendants.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff also seeks statutory interest from the date of commencement of this action, as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest on personal injury judgments) and costs as allowed by law.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Costs of this action as allowed by law, pursuant to G.L. c. 261 and related provisions;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and Mass. R. Civ. P. 38, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
